Lars Clausen writes:
[...]
> > Anyway, if you want to look at the raw contents of your compressed
> > ARCs, just use zmore:
> > 
> > (0) tree% zmore ARN-20040708211401-00000.arc.gz
> 
> Yes, now, if you happen to have zmore.  Solaris doesn't come with it,
> for instance (and BTW, I prefer zless:).

Yes, of course you need to have z(more|less)... Linux, FreeBSD, and
Mac OS X all come with it. 

> But if you read RFC 1952 (the gzip standard), you'll notice that "The
> data format defined by this specification does not attempt to provide
> random access to compressed data...", which is essentially what we're
> trying to make it do.  That some tools work with that is just luck, some
> tools won't.  In fact, .arc.gz files are not gzip files according to the
> standard, but a concatenation of multiple gzip files (not zlib streams).

You are right, of course. The use of multiple gzip files concatenated
together is a clever way of getting around the random access limitation.

> What you can't do right now is skip past blocks without decompressing
> them, as you don't know their compressed lengths.  That means that
> extracting CDX files is more time-consuming, as you'll have to read and
> uncompress about 100 times as much material.  

True. The way I handle this in libarc is that I inflate and examine
enough of the record to extract the URL header, and from there I just
inflate the rest of the gzip entry without investigating the bytes. It
is time consuming, but it works. To test this, I just instrumented my
arcdump utility to report the time spent building its internal index:
on an 100MB gziped ARC file containing 11,941 entries it took 2.8
seconds on my 1.8 GHz G5. Assuming that you spend those 2.8 seconds
once to generate a CDX file, it isn't horrible, I suppose.

> Of course, the proposed idea of having the metadata

The more I thought about your idea on my drive into the office this
morning, the more I like it. Keep the URL record uncompressed, and
include a compression method and offset to the start of the next
entry.

> That would violate one of the requirements set forth in
> http://www.archive.org/web/researcher/ArcFileFormat.php:
[...]

Noted.

> To understand a gzipped ARC file, you either have to have an index or
> you must parse and uncompress it from the beginning.  There's no going
> into the middle of it and finding the headers.  While it's not the
> integrity of the file that is destroyed, it does make index-less work on
> the file a lot harder.

You can't go into the middle of an uncompressed ARC file and easily
find the headers either.

It also depends on the tools. With libarc working with index-less
files is trivial.

    -tree
